intro: Satyrium papyretorum, commonly known as the lesser marsh-orchid, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to wetlands and marshy areas in Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, pale greenish-yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with linear, grass-like leaves that are often submerged or partially submerged in water. Its roots are fibrous and adapted to thrive in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Satyrium papyretorum plays an important ecological role in wetland ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various insect species.
